events.description: The release of the monthly Purchasing Managers' Index for the Irish services sector showing a decline to 54.5.

facts.fact_text: The AIB Ireland Services PMI declined to 54.5 in January 2026 from 54.8 in December.

evidences.evidence_text: The AIB Ireland Services PMI declined slightly to 54.5 in January 2026, down from December’s 54.8

facts.fact_text: New business growth in the Irish services sector slowed to a five-month low.

evidences.evidence_text: new business growth slowed to a five-month low.

facts.fact_text: Input cost inflation reached a three-month high and exceeded the long-run trend.

evidences.evidence_text: input cost inflation accelerated to a three-month high and above the long-run trend

facts.fact_text: Output price inflation reached its highest level since May 2024.

evidences.evidence_text: output price inflation accelerated to the highest since May 2024

facts.fact_text: Employment growth was stronger than the long-run survey average.

evidences.evidence_text: firms continued to raise employment solidly, and at a rate stronger than the long-run survey average.

claims.claim_text: Business sentiment in the services sector remains optimistic despite moderating from December.
claims.author: AIB

evidences.evidence_text: Looking ahead, business sentiment remained optimistic, but moderated from December.

claims.claim_text: The expansion in the services sector was the softest since September.
claims.author: AIB

evidences.evidence_text: marking the softest expansion since September.

evidence.evidence_text: In response to the rise in new business, firms continued to raise employment solidly
input cost inflation accelerated to a three-month high and above the long-run trend
The moderation in services sector growth came as new business growth slowed to a five-month low.
